title: A souped-up international line-up at The Brussels Comic Strip Festival
text:
A souped-up international line-up at The Brussels Comic Strip Festival Published on : Thursday, July 30, 2015
The big top at The Brussels Comic Strip Festival, which runs from 4 through 6 September in the Parc de Bruxelles, will play host to a greatly expanded international programme. In fact, for the first time The Brussels Comic Strip Festival will include a Manga section and an international pavilion where the public can discover the “Ninth Art” culture of twelve countries from around the world.
The Manga section
This year Manga will be featured under the big top as an overarching theme.
Two bookstores operated by big name publishers will put Manga front and centre. On one side will be Kana, a specialist in Manga publishing, presenting its catalogue and a signing session with author Elsa Brants. On the other will be an area dedicated to Glénat Publishing, which will offer its own array of Japanese comic books.
At the same time, Manga initiation workshops, drawing workshops, and a photo corner will be organised by Belgotaku, the Manga fan community. To add some Manga colour to the three-day celebration, the Belgian association Be Cosplay will parade characters straight from comic strips under the big top in handmade costumes.
Young people won’t be left out and will be able to discover Japanese comic books in the kids’ zone, completely decked out for the occasion.
The international pavilion
The twelve countries represented will present comic strips and exhibitions in order to share their “Ninth Art” culture, with a special emphasis on young artists.
The China pavilion will exhibit twelve artists along with a selection of their works. There visitors will be able to discover the singular charm of contemporary comic strips, reflecting Chinese style, spirit, and dreams
Alongside an exhibition of three Korean artists, Yeonsik Hong, Ancco, and Junggi Kim, South Korea also welcomes Kim Jung-Gi. Author of the “Spy Games” comic book, the artist is especially renowned for his live performances on giant canvasses that he puts on at The Brussels Comic Strip Festival.
Prolific Finnish comic strips, little known among general European audiences, will woo visitors to The Brussels Comic Strip Festival. The Finnish Comic Strip Society and artist Reetta Niemensivu will present their vision for the Ninth Art with humour and levity.
The Autrique House has been collaborating for several years with Havana (Cuba) on the “Havana Comic Strip Laboratory.” The exhibition of new Cuban authors, including a meeting with one of them, immerses visitors in Old Havana.
Europe’s largest and oldest comic strip festival Lucca Comics & Games of Italy will show off its “fumetti” will a special emphasis on humorous comic strips. Artists Giuseppe Palumbo and Sio, known for their off-the-wall humour, will face off in a “comic strip battle.” May the funniest man win!
The Czech Republic, where the comic strip is also a big cultural phenomenon, will be represented by the publisher Meander House and one of its authors, Lela Geislerova. Encounters, signing sessions, and drawing workshops are all scheduled.
Finally, six countries and regions that are members of the European Union’s National Institutes of Culture (EUNIC) have signed up. So France, Hungary, Romania, Poland, Estonia, and the Basque region will team up for exhibitions, activities, improvisation games, live drawing, and signing sessions.
